hypothesis: Of 8 swarm coordination patterns mapped to institutional reform (L-410), 4 achieve HIGH transferability (low infra + low culture cost): compaction/sunset, expect-act-diff/accountability, anti-windup/stall-detection, context-handoffs. Quorum governance achieves LOW transferability (high infra + high culture cost).
method: Scored each of 8 swarm patterns from L-410 on 3 transferability dimensions: (1) infrastructure cost (LOW=process change only, MED=new tools/systems, HIGH=structural/constitutional change), (2) culture cost (LOW=no behavior change, MED=training needed, HIGH=deep norm shift), (3) legal requirements (LOW=executive order, MED=legislation, HIGH=constitutional amendment). Combined score: HIGH transfer if infra<=LOW and culture<=MED; MED if any dimension is MED without HIGH; LOW if any dimension is HIGH. Cross-validated against real-world reform examples from regulatory literature (sunset clauses, GPRA, OIRA review, federalism debates).

dataset.source: L-410 (swarm-institution transfer map), L-407 (compaction failure thesis), L-409 (expect-act-diff as policy accountability), domains/human-systems/DOMAIN.md

patterns.evidence: Sunset clauses already exist in ~15 US states for agency review. UK Red Tape Challenge (2011-2014) eliminated 3,000+ regulations. Implementation requires only legislative procedure, not structural change.
patterns.real_world_example: Colorado sunset review eliminated 24 state agencies 1977-2000

patterns.human_reform: Policy outcome accountability (measurable targets + diff review)
patterns.evidence: US GPRA (1993) mandated strategic plans with performance measures. UK Public Service Agreements defined targets. Implementation requires executive directive, not legislation. Culture cost: agencies resist measurable targets because failure becomes visible.
patterns.real_world_example: GPRA (1993) + GPRA Modernization Act (2010): measurable targets for all federal agencies

patterns.human_reform: Process stall detection / zombie process elimination
patterns.evidence: GAO High Risk List identifies stalled federal programs. Inspector General offices detect process stalls. No structural change needed - existing oversight mechanisms can be enhanced with automated age-based triggers (direct parallel to maintenance.py stale lane detection).
patterns.real_world_example: GAO High Risk List (since 1990): identifies programs with chronic management failures

patterns.human_reform: Structured transition briefings / institutional memory systems
patterns.evidence: Presidential transition briefings exist but are unstructured. UK Cabinet Manual standardized handoffs in 2011. NASA Lessons Learned system (LLIS) provides structured knowledge transfer. Culture cost: incoming leaders often discard predecessor context.
patterns.real_world_example: Presidential Transition Act (1963, amended 2010): structured but not template-enforced

patterns.evidence: EU concurrent regulatory review exists but requires coordination infrastructure. Singapore parallel agency processing reduces licensing time 60%. Needs new coordination tools but not constitutional change.
patterns.real_world_example: Singapore BizFile+ (2004): parallel multi-agency business registration

patterns.evidence: Requires constitutional-level restructuring of decision authority. Historical examples (Swiss canton system, EU qualified majority voting) took decades. Deep cultural norm shift from hierarchical to distributed authority. No rapid implementation path.
patterns.real_world_example: EU qualified majority voting (Lisbon Treaty 2009): 50+ years to implement

patterns.evidence: US Administrative Procedure Act (1946) allows rulemaking petitions, but processing time averages 2-5 years. Culture barrier: agencies resist external challenges to established rules. Need both procedural change and cultural shift.
patterns.real_world_example: APA Section 553(e) petition for rulemaking: high barrier, low success rate

patterns.evidence: Requires constitutional-level redistribution of authority. UK devolution (Scotland/Wales/NI) took 20+ years of political effort. Centralized states resist power distribution. Implementation cost is structural, not procedural.
patterns.real_world_example: UK devolution acts (1998): decades of political effort for partial implementation

finding: L-410 prediction CONFIRMED: exactly 4 patterns achieve HIGH transferability (compaction, expect-act-diff, anti-windup, context handoffs) and quorum governance is LOW. The distinguishing factor is that HIGH-transfer patterns require only process changes to existing oversight mechanisms, while LOW-transfer patterns require structural redistribution of authority. Key insight: the 4 HIGH patterns all have real-world partial implementations (sunset clauses, GPRA, GAO High Risk List, Presidential Transition Act), confirming that swarm coordination principles map to existing reform infrastructure.
iso_mapping: ISO-5 (stabilizing feedback): the 4 HIGH-transfer patterns are all negative feedback mechanisms (detect drift, correct). LOW-transfer patterns require structural reorganization (positive feedback / phase transition). ISO-13 (integral windup): compaction and anti-windup directly address accumulation-without-discharge, the core bureaucratic failure mode. ISO-4 (phase transition): LOW-transfer patterns (quorum, colony nesting) require a phase transition in governance structure, not incremental reform.
confidence: DESIGN (n=8 patterns scored, cross-validated against regulatory literature)
next_steps: Advance F-HS1: quantify regulatory accumulation rate and sunset clause effectiveness using CFR page count data (L-407 baseline: 20K pages 1960 to 185K pages 2024)
Advance F-HS3: identify jurisdictions with mandatory sunset review for controlled comparison of policy quality outcomes
Test whether the 4 HIGH-transfer patterns form a minimal viable reform bundle (compaction + accountability + stall-detection + handoffs)
